respondent.name: ERIC H. HOLDER, JR., ATTORNEY GENERAL

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 11-702, Moncrieffe v. Holder. Mr. Goldstein.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Excuse me.  You use that word, "regularly."  Do you have statistics on that? Were they provided in the briefs?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It's -- it's a massive amount of conduct that -- that the statute contemplates? The statutory scheme -- I just didn't hear.  I just didn't hear.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: When you -- now, Mr. Goldstein, when you say, "this case," is there any proof in the record that there was a small amount and no -- no remuneration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.  I don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Material weight says less than 1 ounce --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- parentheses, "Approximate weight is 1" -- 1 -- oh, I see, 1.3 grams.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You -- we are discussing the categorical approach, but let's assume he had pled guilty.  And in his allocution, he had admitted to not a smaller amount or to remuneration.  Would -- would an immigration judge, under the argument you're making today, have to ignore that allocution?  Or would he be able to apply the modified approach and find this gentleman an aggravated felon?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's the issue with this case.  None of these immigrants are being let out automatically.  They are still felons subject to removal.  The only issue is whether --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well -- they're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- they're still subject to removal --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- either way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- I see that.  There's something I really don't understand in these cases because the other cases, our precedent's been around a long time, so I would have guessed that, under that precedent in these other statutes, the obvious thing to do -- the obvious puzzle here is not the Federal statute, it's the State statute, what is this thing he was convicted of about? So you'd pick up the phone, and you'd phone, at random, four U.S. attorneys -- not U.S. attorneys, but four State attorneys --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- who work with the statute in Georgia, and say, now, look, the indictment here says possession with intent to distribute, and I can show from the documents that it's a tiny amount. Now, is it your policy, if he was selling it, to charge under the sell?  Is it your policy if he's not selling it to charge under intent to distribute?  Is it totally random whether you say sell or intent to distribute? What's your policy?  Okay? Then we get some answers.  Then we'd have an idea whether what you're saying is right.  Now, you could do that, but they could do it, too.  Anyone could do it.  And then we'd have some actual facts about whether this charge -- really, it corresponds to the misdemeanor or the felony in the Federal statute. So why -- I'm not -- I mean, that isn't a brain -- that isn't -- doesn't require -- it's not rocket science, okay?  So why has no one done it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You don't have to say, "never."  The question is what kind of a statute is this State statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the kind of statute that it is, is a statute that is used to prosecute people --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- with small amounts when they don't sell.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If your version of what that felon intends to distribute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The distinction there is really picked up by the district attorneys. And if it's not, then they may be right, because -- because then intent to distribute may well often include, as it does under Federal law, people who sell stuff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  Okay.  You didn't. In any words, nobody did it. So my other question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- which is the only other one I really have, aside from making that suggestion. But here, what happened to this person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He was -- was he sentenced under 16-13-2(a)?  That is, was he sentenced to probation?  Which would be evidence in your favor, I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But was he, or wasn't he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  If he was, what it says in this provision is that the Court may without entering a judgment of guilt.  So there was no judgment of guilt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And it says, if he completes it, he then is discharged without court adjudication of guilt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And -- and shall not be deemed a conviction, it says for purposes of this code.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, why are we saying he was convicted of anything?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And that question's not before us today.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  Well, isn't the reason we don't look at the particular facts and particular case and don't depose four district attorneys, is that the Court has adopted a categorical approach precisely to avoid that type of inquiry in -- whatever it is, 750,000 cases?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no, I'm sorry. We don't need that because we've adopted a categorical approach.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: 841(b)(1)(D) lists the elements and conviction in -- Georgia, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Conviction in Georgia under their provision satisfies -- has each of those elements.  And under our categorical approach, that's the end of the inquiry.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: They want to do that at the tail end, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Again, I didn't hear.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: They want to do it in every --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: At the -- at the beginning of the State prosecution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Before you get on -- I didn't understand that to be their position at all.  I mean, I suppose we -- I certainly will ask them because they're probably better able to articulate their position, but --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Goldstein, it's because they are trying to mirror the Federal statute, which makes the small amount and no remuneration, makes that like an affirmative defense.  The burden is on the defendant to show those two things, to get out from under the main statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So what the Government is suggesting is as close to the Federal statute as you can get.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You said Carachuri.  That case involved, in -- in order to hold for the government, you would have to go outside the record of the State conviction.  You'd have to add something that wasn't in the State conviction. And it's the same thing here.  To get to where you want to go, you have to add something that isn't in the State conviction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what is the conviction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What does the conviction mean?  You say the categorical approach.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is -- is it the categorical statute under which you have been convicted or, as you seem to be saying, the indictment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is he convicted of that? Or is he convicted of violating Georgia Code 16-13, whatever it is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Goldstein, assuming he was convicted of that, as you suggest, you have an underinclusiveness problem.  The Government has an overinclusiveness problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: If you assume that this statute covers and is regularly used to cover both sets of people, both people with these very minor offenses and people with much more major offenses --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- the at least apparent attractiveness of the government's position is that they've tried to cure their overinclusiveness problem. And they have done it by sticking on -- and -- you know, one can ask where this comes from in the statute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- but they have done it by sticking on something that attempts to address their overinclusiveness problem, so that people who are really misdemeanants get classified as misdemeanants, and people who are really aggravated felons get classified that way. And you have no similar cure for your underinclusiveness problem.  So why shouldn't we go with their problem, which at least attempts to solve this problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I don't follow --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- your answer because I think you have to concede that, under your view, a lot of people who are convicted under the Georgia statute who had a significant quantity, which they intended to distribute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- for remuneration --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- many of those people would -- under your view of the statute, many of those people would -- would not have committed an aggravated felony.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you have that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- a large underinclusiveness problem, which you haven't solved.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But all that follows from, in Carachuri, the government wanted to go outside the record.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do you think that the Attorney General could just issue some kind of directive telling all administrative law judges and officials to deny cancellation of removal to anybody who commits these kinds of offenses?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Would it -- would it be permissible -- I had the same question.  Would it be permissible --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Or would you be back up here saying that this violates the statute?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  Could you remind me what the "it" is that you're talking about?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's an order from the Attorney General --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- to the immigration judges --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- to?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: To do the exact same thing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- but through --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- an Attorney General directive.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you have any statistics -- if you take the whole universe of convictions under the Georgia statute, what percentage of them are for these minor offenses and what are for the major?  Do we have any handle on that at all?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Goldstein, there are at least 93 cases, all right?  So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And I don't know and I'm not going to ask you to prove to me how the burden of proof was met or not met in those.  But let me give you a different hypothetical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Let's assume Georgia has the Federal statute, but in -- differently than the Federal statute, it has a sale-distribution provision, and it has a small amount, no remuneration statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What would happen in those States?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  Go ahead.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Your use of the statistics, I think, assumes that Georgia and other States are prosecuting every case that comes before them because that's how you get -- you know, of these 750,000 nationwide, so much more than must involve tiny amounts. But, of course, perhaps they don't prosecute the cases involving tiny amounts, so that most of those cases, or some percentage of them, may in fact also involve the serious type of conduct addressed by the Federal statute.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Shah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What's the free pass? The free pass is mandatory as opposed to discretionary deportation, correct?  So the free pass is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But those convicted individuals would still be subject to deportation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And nothing would stop the INS judge from considering the amount of drugs, correct, that the individual actually was involved in, and that could be introduced through hearsay -- through almost any document, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, do you -- do you suggest that the immigration judges don't know that and that they wouldn't weigh that desire heavily in a case in which a -- the convicted individual is proven to have sold the larger amount?  You still think they are going to cancel?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, will you pause right there.  I don't -- you just made the argument that your position on Castro-Rodriguez is wrong.  You say Congress took away the Attorney General's discretion. Then you come back and say, well, we're going to exercise that discretion under -- under Castro-Rodriguez, and this Petitioner in particular can take advantage of it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is that -- is the authority for that Castro-Rodriguez?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is the authority for that the decision in Castro-Rodriguez?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Shah, the Board may have been doing these inquiries, but I just don't understand the statutory argument because the way the statute -- the way your own statutory argument runs is that if the conviction -- the State conviction, was a conviction for possession with intent to distribute, then those are the elements of a Federal -- of a Federal felony. And so the person -- and an aggravated felony.  So you say, under the elements approach, this person has committed an aggravated felony.  And the statutory directive is that, when a person has committed an aggravated, felony, he is deportable, and there is no exercise of discretion that can come into play. And so your whole back-end process, which says, oh, well, maybe not, maybe he's not automatically deportable, it doesn't come from the statute, and it seems to run into the statutory language, which says an aggravated felon must be deported, the end.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, that's what the statute says, and that's what your own statutory analysis says.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: This is --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead.  I'm sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you've answered Justice Kagan's question by -- she said, doesn't your own interpretation of this statute require the opposite result and -- or the -- the harsh result? And you say, well, suppose Congress wrote a statute this way.  But that wasn't her question.  The question is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You -- you said that Congress could write a new statute.  Of course, Congress could write a new statute, but what about this one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No, I'll just read you, Mr. Shah, this sentence from your brief -- and I could read you a thousand of these in your brief.  "Because Petitioner's Georgia conviction necessarily established that he knowingly possessed marijuana with the specific intent to distribute it, that conviction constitutes an aggravated felony." Well, if that conviction constitutes an aggravated felony, he has to be deported, and there is no exercise of discretion that this statute allows.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, now, you've just put in words into your brief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- and -- and really, truly, you say this 10 or 15 times.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But this is -- this is a new position for the government.  My understanding is that you -- your clients were on the other side of this position in Castro-Rodriguez itself; is that not correct?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that was a change in the government's position, wasn't it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So what does -- in a case in which the Attorney General can cancel removal, putting aside this case, what are the sort of things he looks at in deciding whether or not to cancel removal?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So one of the things, presumably, is the amount of drugs involved, whether they were for intent to distribute for remuneration -- all the sorts of things that you say he can consider under the provision that says he does not have the authority to cancel removal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Each time you get -- you say that, you get back into the hole that Justice Kagan has been asking you to climb out of.  If -- if Congress' intent was to bar discretion, then I'm not quite sure how you get to your alternative to get out of your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- overinclusiveness argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do -- do you agree with Mr. Goldstein when he says, in reality, it's not an affirmative defense, that the defendant never has to prove the amount?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry, counselor. I -- the government can do it very easily.  If you have less than an ounce of marijuana and nothing else from which you can infer an intent to sell or distribute, and you have no proof that this individual's engaged in drug trafficking, what more does a defendant have to show?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How does it raise his burden of proof?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I guess my point is that one, which is don't the facts that the government have either show it or not show it in virtually every instance?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It would be less than an ounce.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can I go back to your substantive argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  This is a -- you are right.  It's an unusually crafted statute.  And really, what the issue is, generally, what you have with lesser included offenses is you have a base offense and then an enhancement that goes up.  You commit the base offense --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- of burglary, but if you did it with an explosive or you did it with a dangerous weapon, it goes up.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And applying the categorical approach is relatively easy there because either the State offense includes the addition or it doesn't. This is sort of in reverse.  You've got a statute with the same elements that can be either a misdemeanor or a felony.  And you're saying it can be either under the CSA, but we have to assume it's the greater because --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- of Apprendi, because of -- of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that's under Apprendi.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's the point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Didn't we -- didn't we talk about the categorical approach in footnote 3 of our case in Carachuri?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Where we said that, in talking about the generic Federal offense, whether it's a felony or not, that we can't look at just strictly the elements of the crime, but we have to also look at the sentencing factors because, when we're talking about what constitutes a misdemeanor or a felony under Federal law, we have to look at both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the same elements would go to the misdemeanor.  Really, the issue for me is it could be one or both.  And when do we tell the immigration judge that he can, should, or should not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- choose between the two?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: However you do it, the misdemeanor still has the same three elements.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So how do we choose between it being a misdemeanor or a felony?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Shah, I think the problem with your main argument is that it leads you to a result that you don't want to accept because your main argument is all we've done in our past cases -- and I can argue with this, but your argument is all we've done is compare the elements. But if all we do is compare the elements, then we don't get to your discretionary scheme in which we also admit evidence of -- of the case-specific nature of the offense. I mean, so your arguments all go towards a very purist solution.  And then you say, oh, no, that's a crazy solution.  It's a crazy solution because we would wind up saying that misdemeanants, like this person, like people who are actually convicted under (b)(4) who are clearly misdemeanants, would wind up as aggravated felons and -- and must be deported.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I don't think we really have an agreement --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- because it seems to me that Carachuri actually says we don't just look to elements.  But if we were just to look to elements in the way you're arguing for, we wouldn't get the result that you're arguing for.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And the whole point -- the whole point is that there is no similar provision in the statute at issue in this case, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I don't think that that is quite right, Mr. Shah, because if you read this statute, what it most looks like is that Congress is simply classifying two different kinds of conduct. Congress has the -- the social sharing conduct, and that's in one section.  And the everything else, the more dangerous conduct, is in another section. And so it's not something where it's like, oh, you're trying to get them to negate a specific -- a point.  Congress has created two separate sections, two -- and one is a felony, and one is a misdemeanor. And that's the -- the real way to understand this statute. And then the categorical approach suggests, well, in that case, we accept the underinclusion, rather than the overinclusion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I guess I don't understand, Mr. Shah.  That seems just a question of labeling to me. I mean, why should we -- why should we accept that labeling, rather than, look, what Congress did here was to say that certain kinds of offenses are felonies deserving of grave punishment, and other kinds of offenses are misdemeanors deserving of less than a year in prison, and -- and we see those -- those categories of conduct differently. And if you are saying that if Congress had -- had said two separate offenses, then the categorical approach means that Mr. Goldstein's client wins, I guess I just don't get what in this statute suggests something different from that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Counsel, I thought that when Congress enacted this provision, there was not the distinction between elements and sentencing factors that we now have, that the statute was enacted, in other words, before Apprendi.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That may be, but it certainly goes to your argument that Congress had in mind some distinction between elements and sentencing factors.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If you do not -- if you do not prevail in this case, can you simply solve this problem in the discretionary removal proceedings?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You just say we're going to -- we're going to order you removed, unless you bring in evidence that this was a minor amount, period.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, don't you think it's -- it's, under the law and under administrative practice, that it's an option available to you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, under the -- under the -- do you have the same answer as Mr. Goldstein, that the modified categorical approach wouldn't permit the immigration judge to look at the plea allocution to determine the amount?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So that in -- in many of these cases that we're talking about, it is possible that the plea allocution itself would set out the amounts that the alien sold or show that he sold something --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- and that would take care of this issue of how many people are escaping automatic removal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the vast majority -- the vast majority, in my experience, do -- do say whether the crime was for sale or distribution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are there any other consequences?  We've been talking only about dispensation from removal.  But are there any other consequences that matter?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does that -- does the Castro-Rodriguez proceeding take care of those additional consequences?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sure.  Oh, yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Goldstein, you have three minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But it's the word "punishable," I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So you're thinking, under Georgia law, this is punishable as a felony only if it wasn't a small amount used for personal use, you see, and therefore, they go into the hearing.  It's not punishable as an 841 felony, unless those two things are absent, and therefore, they have the hearing to find out.  And the word "punishable" doesn't appear in the statutes, the other ones that we've construed.  That's what I thought they were doing.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel, counsel. The case is submitted.
